sub_subject.name: Humanities Integration (Literature's Context)
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Humanities Integration (Literature's Context) (Language Arts & Humanities)

objectives.objective_text: Identify a letter written by someone long ago.
Name who wrote it and who read it.
Identify the feelings of the writer.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Identify stories from other countries.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Name heroes from different places.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Identify what a culture thinks is important.
Identify when a character is kind or mean.
Name the helper and the hurter.
Identify the consequences of a lie.
Identify that a story happened a long time ago.
Name things in the story that we don't have today (e.g., horses instead of cars).
Identify how the setting changes the plot.
Identify a picture that matches a story.
Name a song that feels like the book.
Identify the mood in both art and text.
Recall that old letters tell us secrets about the past.
Listen to a speech from history.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Recall that everyone has a story.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Observe that people dress and eat differently in stories.
Recall that we should follow Jesus.
Observe that bad choices make sad endings.
Recall that people in history were real people like us.
Observe how characters dress and talk.
Recall that people paint and write about the same things.
Observe colors that show feelings like words do.
Summarize a diary entry from a historical figure.
Explain why old writing sounds different.
Explain the difference between a primary and secondary source.
Defend the importance of reading original sources over summaries.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Summarize a legend that explains how a country began.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Explain why different cultures value different things.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Explain the concept of a 'Counter-Narrative'.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Defend the Biblical metanarrative as the true story of the world.
Summarize a difficult choice a character had to make.
Explain what conscience is (the voice inside).
Explain the role of repentance in a character's arc.
Defend the need for moral absolutes in storytelling.
Summarize the historical event behind a story (e.g., The Revolutionary War).
Explain what is fact and what is fiction in a historical novel.
Explain the value of learning history through stories.
Defend the use of fiction to illuminate historical truth.
Summarize how a painting tells a story.
Explain how music can make a story scary or happy.
Explain how different art forms express the 'Spirit of the Age'.
Defend the unity of truth, goodness, and beauty across disciplines.
Compare a letter from the Civil War with a modern email.
Analyze the rhetorical style of a historical document (e.g., The Gettysburg Address).
Interpret the tone and purpose of a primary source.
Connect the document to the literature of the same period.
Identify if a character is good or bad.
Name the right thing to do in the story.
Identify the 'Big Idea' (e.g., Friendship, Courage).

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Compare an American hero story with a Japanese hero story.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the 'Founding Myth' of a nation (e.g., Rome's Aeneid vs. America's Pilgrims).

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Interpret how stories create national identity.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Connect cultural narratives to the way people act today.
Compare what you would do with what the character did.
Analyze the complexity of a moral dilemma where there is no easy answer.
Interpret the development of a character's conscience.
Connect the story to the concept of 'Moral Imagination' (practicing being good).
Compare the story with a history textbook account.
Analyze how the author weaves real history into the narrative.
Interpret the accuracy of the historical portrayal.
Connect the characters' struggles to the timeline of events.
Compare a poem about spring with a painting of spring.
Analyze the relationship between Romantic poetry and Romantic painting.
Interpret the term 'Ekphrasis' (writing about art).
Connect a musical era (e.g., Baroque) to its literature.
Evaluate the worldview assumptions in a primary document.
Recall that God wants us to be kind.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the impact of propaganda in cultural storytelling.
Evaluate the distinction between legal righteousness and true virtue in literature.
Evaluate the bias of the author in portraying historical figures.
Evaluate the concept of the 'Gesamtkunstwerk' (Total Art Work).
Synthesize primary source documents with a literary reading of the period.
Synthesize the literary voice of an era through its documents.
Ask 'Why did they do that?'
Summarize the moral lesson of a fable or story.
Explain what the characters believe about right and wrong.
Explain how ideas have consequences in the plot.
Defend a biblical answer to the philosophical questions raised.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Construct a comparison of the metanarratives of Western vs. Eastern civilizations.

objectives.sub_topic_name: How Cultures Tell Their Own Story
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the role of literature in shaping or reflecting culture.
Construct an ethical critique of a protagonist's decisions.
Synthesize the power of story to shape moral intuition.
Construct a critique of a historical novel's fidelity to the era.
Construct a comparative essay on a theme (e.g., War) in literature, art, and music.
Synthesize the cultural output of a specific historical period.
Construct a literary analysis of a non-literary text (e.g., The Magna Carta or The Federalist Papers).
Compare a wise choice with a foolish choice.
Analyze the ethical dilemma faced by a protagonist.
Interpret the author's answer to 'What is the good life?'.
Connect the story to biblical truth.
Evaluate the consistency of the author's worldview.
Synthesize literature as a testing ground for philosophical ideas.
Construct an analysis of the philosophical underpinnings of a novel (e.g., Existentialism in Camus).
